alternatives.transcript: I wish I could stand here and say that we're in the same kind of position on Salem we're not you can see upsides to the Winston business hopefully for the first time in years on Salem we're working hard on a new positioning we're not playing around with Menthol levels we're trying to figure out who is Salem person is and how can we help that person feel good about their association with Salem on Camel

everybody hears about camel sometimes you're kind of tired of hearing about it maybe because you sort of see the sheer volume kind of hang in there kind of flat and say is this thing really turned around well I think this year is the year we're going to see that thing really turn why we're going to improve the availability of box styles Jim told you all the growth was unbox Styles and that's been a limiter to camels growth the other piece of why camels work in is the war in the store side camel has been the one brand last year that really did a lot of in-store promotion stuff

so we had both sides going it had great advertising and a great one the store initiative you got more gosh-darn premiums Ed and stuff on that brand than anything I've ever seen in my life but that kind of thing works

the last point to make on Camel is the objective for Camel is not just to increase the eleven percent of the market that's young adults is to increase the whole darn business Advantage right now on Vantage want to same kind of position on sale we're not really exactly sure what the right positioning for that brand is going forward but we're working on it as fast as we know how therefore in 1991 we're going to shift some of the marketing

the money to do more in store promotion to defend that brand on a longer term basis Vantage is probably our brand because of its Heritage where some new technologies can be applied because the preliminary research on Vantage says that vanish smokers like to think they're a little smarter than the average Joe and so they'll make the little trade-off they think through the purchase better so therefore some of our new technologies May apply well to the Vantage brand

we've got to almost successes going on on new brands and boy would that be a record nobody else does that is a very very hard thing to do and if we can get one of those things to work that can be a huge Victory one full share market Point market share point in this industry is worth 125 million bucks if we can get one of these things to work bottom line
saving segment

and there's two things going on there there's a lot of new brands that are subject Eric's and they're being marketed heavily

you can't they can't continue to mark them that heavily on the kind of money that they're making on those Brands that's got to Abate a little bit and right now you have a lot of people trying them so we've got to respond to that but that's the spirit of that fighting brand strategy under L we do not want to lose our savings position we do not want to lose our volume in this business because we have to maintain a savings presence out there otherwise we lose our merchandising leverage in the store across our whole business so we have two are on the volume side
for merchandising reasons and then for obvious reasons in the factory as well we can't just try to maximize earnings on that brand

we then have to figure out how we're going to take our savings Brands and put all those together to create an attractive savings proposition for the company including our private label best value brand which really can submit our relationships with the accounts and block sub generics in many cases from those accounts

and again we're working on that one hard other key issues for 1991 so we've got a Mary guidance and counsel and direction from Winston-Salem with a little more entrepreneurial General management creativity in the field and that's the challenge we have in the sales and marketing group to do that in 1991 but how do you find the right balance between what goes on in Winston-Salem and what goes on in the field that's very tricky from Winston-Salem we've got to provide

National Direction have folks in the field understand what we're trying to do with our Brands they need to understand the product and positioning and we control the advertising out of Winston-Salem and direct marketing of course

but in the field ask yourself who knows more about that stuff who knows more about individual store programs who knows more about whether a beanbag promotion at work in Boston didn't go work in Texas who knows more about what brand should go up on a particular display at a particular store

because not all the brand sell the same every way camel sells well in the west coast Winston does better in the East and the South but we put the same brand up everywhere so we're no we're not doing it right and then who knows more about selling sales organization knows a little bit more about what goes on the right marketing organization knows more about what's going on on the left

how do you pull that together without having total chaos to think about Our Brands going across the top of this slide Winston-Salem camel Doral vanish now and new technology Brands that's the 90% of the prophet and the down the left hand side the sticks six things you have to do to drive market share up got to do the R&D development process right you've got to do the advertising right you got to promote two people in the home right like direct marketing you've got to promote in the store right war in the store we've been talking about you got a merchandising rights

right get the right Brands up in the right quantities attractively displayed and then you got to sell an individual program to an individual retail otherwise you're not in the Shelf go to all six of those things a brand business unit is designed to optimize the total package across all those functions on a given brand

and that is the right philosophy to run this business with otherwise we have people scramble around in different directions we don't don't optimize the total package for each individual brand and that's the brand business units job their job is to involve the entire company to work as a team and you'll notice there's no pyramid on this chart there's no who reports to who on this chart a brand business unit manager is really a person who brings all those functions together to work as a team and you take the organization lies you throw them away

because that's how you make Advantage business decisions the reason why you have the organization lines is for reporting for salary increases and promotions not to make Advantage business decisions this helps you make Advantage business decisions because everybody's involved in the decision not just the person who is in the center of that chart because we can out-execute Philip Morris productively like to use the words fast break is on a fast break you got to have rebounders passers and scores no one's more important than the other guy so the guy at the end gots the

points but it doesn't work without all three that's the kind of spirit we're looking for as a company and in our sales and marketing group I just want to re-emphasize that Winston is our number one company priority we're not going to get the brand turned around in in six months we're going to start the rebuilding process you saw how long it took on Camel but it can be done Winston it will be done on

Winston and I need everyone who is involved in any way with the Winston Brand to make that their personal number one priority we've got to get the job done and we've got to get it done right I'm going to cover some of our plans and a few other areas of the company

in technology will continue working on prototypes of improved products as well as enhancing the quality of our current products this includes work on our ingredients such as modifying our reconstituted sheet to enhance mildness taste and nicotine properties we're also focusing our resources on the top market-driven priorities which are reduction and elimination of sidestream smoke enhancing taste and smoker satisfaction in the lower term
a level products and enhancing the aroma of our products
on the quality front it is vital that we continue to enhance the quality of our products in 1991 and Beyond

we spent a lot of money in this company to attract new smokers but think about this for a minute if we could stop just 10% of the people who switch away from Our Brands to a competitive brand would mean three tenths of a SharePoint and fifty million dollars to the bottom line of this company at some measure of how important quality can be to us and having completed our extensive

work on a business strategy last year we concluded it's vitally important that we also develop a well thought out strategy on Information Technology it's critical not only for marketing and sales but also that we have a comprehensive company-wide strategy on Information Technology the study is just beginning and we expect to complete it by mid-year

productivity we will continue to enhance our efficiency in all areas ranging from manufacturing processes to our promotional programs to administrative issues we intend to continue emphasizing cost conservation and will benefit from Savings in areas such as Leaf purchases wrapping material sourcing during the coming year we will also benefit economically from the closing of the downtown plants last year and automation

efforts in our D from new efficiencies and improvements in our couponing and promotional programs from the merchandising program in which old fixtures are refurbished and from computer and Telecommunications efficiencies
but with all these productivity efforts we will be spending more on consumer-driven needs such as advertising and Merchandising Marketplace performance is Key to Our Success

cost management is and will continue to be important but it's an aid not a strategy we can't save our way to success but we can strengthen our Marketplace performance when we take money out of less essential things and put them into high priority business building programs instead
our 1991 plan includes very substantial investments in building our business you personally must take control

and personal responsibility for cost control in your function you have to take the lead in making Intelligent Decisions about trade-offs distinguishing between what's nice to have and what is vital for our success for decades our business rode a rising tide rising consumption or flat consumption with large price increases
the game wasn't that hard
those days are over
Now Rising prices send consumption down Rising anti-smoking sentiment precipitates more declines but we intend to swim upstream and gain a larger portion of that business
how do we do this we have to be cost efficient
we have to be tactically responsive able to react overnight
two opportunities or threats
we have to become a real team
it's companies had to spend a lot of time over the last year and a half deciding where it wants to go that's done now
we now have to spend our time on how we're going to get there
and that's by superb execution in everything we do every day
we can't win just with brilliant strategies we will win only if the strategies are brilliantly executed
otherwise they're not worth the paper they're printed on
we have to take the time to make sure we get things right getting all the input that's required in the early stages I think of this is getting people's fingerprints all over an idea early on
I'm not talking about controls and approvals here talking about input and advice ideas cooperation coordination commitment

it's counterproductive to plan on a product that Rd can't design and Manufacturing can't make a retail program that isn't effective at the field sales level or any kind of program that will require the help of functions you haven't bothered to consult so also counterproductive if someone seeks your advice and your hold back from giving an objective opinion for whatever reason
even though we're pushing for greater teamwork we've made some mistakes in this business that could have been avoided if someone had spoken up
there were instances where someone saw a potential problem
did not bring it to attention
because they didn't think it was their job to do so they didn't think it was part of their turf
that attitude is costing this company and we can't afford that price
but once people have agreed on a common result
then we run like hell in that direction
then we don't take time to form more committees and write more memos because that opportunity may be gone before the committee can meet on
a bad habit we must obliterate is a tendency toward looking inwardly instead of outwardly we have to focus our attention and our energy on the power struggle in the marketplace
not only internal power struggles
this industry profitability comes to the winner of the war in the store the long-term viability of this industry will be shaped by our success in the store and in the anti-smoking War
we have enough battles to fight on the outside we can't afford any Civil Wars inside the company
I think we've made noteworthy progress and encouraging more teamwork around the company but I'm damned impatient with the pace of that change
all the studies you read tell you top management makes that commitment and sets the right kind of example it takes one year per layer to filter down through an organization
we haven't got that kind of time
we've got to speed things up if we're going to achieve this company's Mission teamwork is where our power lies it's where our leverage lives
and either you become part of that power or you become a drain on the power most of the employees in this company work for somebody sitting in this room today
you'd better not only be setting the right example yourself but also actively promoting more teamwork among your people and their counterparts in other areas
one of your key account abilities is to build team RJ are a team that has a passion for winning
we're going to win we need teamwork we need superb execution and we need a passion for winning
we need those things our mission statement talks about working for smokers providing Superior service within and outside the company
and both for our own self-satisfaction and for Marketplace success we need to put some pain back on the guys who have caused us pain let's look at those guys for a moment
Philip Morris ended last year with the trade load somewhere between 19 and 20 billion units we all know what that feels like

we also know how good it feels to have it behind us their problem is still in front of them pm has said publicly again and again they will continue to grow volume share and produce double-digit earnings creases year in year out
well I got two out of three last year playing the game straight up
how'd they get the third
it loaded so you start to load and I'll gets bigger and it gets bigger

and if you keep trying to put 10 pounds in a 5-pound sack sooner or later it blows up on you and in the meantime it distracts you from setting directions for the long-term prosperity of their business the M will suffer some other distractions this year as well Maxwell plans to retire this year their chairman and a lot of people are jockeying for position right now

let's have some fun putting some pain back on the people who've been such a pain to us I was struck recently by an article that appeared in Industry Week Magazine called The Power of being responsible
I wholeheartedly support the author's notion that responsibility is not a function of your job title
responsibility is a commitment you make
and yes it's a risk you take
I can't give you responsibility
you must take it
you're not a leader just because you have the word manager in your title
you are a leader only if you assume responsibility make a commitment take risks and push yourself
if we don't choose to be responsible to be leaders to be winners then we are setting ourselves up to lose
show me your responsibility
